Award.AwardTitle: Quantum Monte Carlo studies of rovibrational dynamics and quantum solvation in ultracold bosonic clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
David Farrelly of Utah State University is supported by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop a new theoretical and computational approach to the quantum Diffusion Monte Carlo (DMC) method. Application will be made to molecular and cluster dynamics. In the proposed algorithm, the nodal hypersurfaces of wave functions - a key input to DMC calculations - are computed and improved on-the-fly throughout the calculation. The nodal search is formulated as a multi-dimensional optimization problem, and is solved using genetic algorithms. Both methodological and algorithmic developments are underway and these will allow efficient utilization of current and future high-end parallel computers. Simulations of problems of current interest are being performed: these include the spectroscopy and dynamics of molecules and molecular clusters doped into small bosonic droplets of helium-4 atoms or para-hydrogen molecules. Bosonic solvent droplets have been used experimentally as nanocryostats to form exotic species and aggregates, as chemical nanoreactors to isolate otherwise unstable reaction intermediates, and as spectroscopic matrices to study large organic molecules and nanostructures.

Farrelly and his coworkers are developing a new theoretical and computational approach to Quantum Monte Carlo algorithms used for investigating the quantum dynamics of complex molecular systems, including clusters of atoms. Usually one of the inputs to these algorithms is the nodal structure of the quantum wavefunctions, i.e., the places where the wavefunction is zero. Unfortunately, this structure is not usually known prior to the calculation so it must be "guessed at". In this project, the nodal structure is computed "on the fly" during the calculation using state-of-the art optimization methods, leading to a more accurate calculation. Quantum Monte Carlo methods are widely used in fields such as the rational design of advanced new materials, simulations of processes important in atmospheric chemistry (e.g., aerosol formation), and cold-atom physics (e.g., quantum computing and developing essentially noise-free atomic analogs of electronics using cold atoms). Undergraduate and graduate students, including those from underrepresented groups, are being trained in state-of-the art computational methods. The resulting computer program is being designed so as to be useful and broadly accessible to other researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New chemistry and physics often emerge from studies of matter in extreme environments. These may include systems subjected to very high pressures and/or temperatures or, alternatively, to very low temperatures close to absolute zero. At very low temperature matter may behave very differently as compared to more normal conditions. For example, helium-4 becomes a superfluid liquid at just 2.172 degrees above absolute zero and remains a liquid as the temperature is lowered further. Given current experimental methodologies it is possible to study very tiny droplets of superfluid liquid helium. These droplets can serve as microscopic, ultracold isolation chambers to understand the behavior of a variety of molecules or small clusters including, for example, DNA bases, amino acids or even proteins. These types of experimental studies may be relevant to the study of neurodegenerative diseases associated with the formation of misfolded protein structures (e.g., Alzheimer’s disease).

The experimental capacity to generate these droplets has given rise to the following question: How big does a droplet have to be in order for it to behave as a superfluid?

Our research addresses this question. It involves studying tiny droplets of helium-4 -- containing as few as 1 – 20 – helium-4 atoms and at temperatures of about 0.38 K. These droplets are doped with other atoms, molecules or clusters. An objective of our work is to understand the interactions between the dopant atoms or molecules and the droplet itself. This knowledge may provide insight into the behavior of some of the larger systems mentioned previously. Our work requires solving the Schroedinger equation accurately on a computer.

Physically small though these droplets are, they nevertheless represent a significant challenge to modern many-body quantum physics.  The problem is further compliacted by the delicate nature of the various interactions. The most direct way to treat them is, perhaps, using Quantum Monte Carlo methods. To sort out the role of quantum statistics and dopant interactions in producing superfluidity in microscopic droplets we have developed a new fixed-quantum diffusion Monte Carlo method (DMC).  The diffusion Monte Carlo method is straightforward and accurate for ground (lowest energy) states. For higher energy states, approximations must be introduced which assume that key properties of the target wave functions are known in advance – a sort of chicken and egg problem.  We have addressed this problem by developing a genetic algorithm version of DMC in which nodal hypersurfaces are computed systematically and on-the-fly within the DMC procedure.  We applied this method to study carbon monoxide (CO) dopants in these small droplets and found that the CO molecule may undergo almost free-rotation and that the droplet may exhibit superfluidity for as few as 4-5 helium-4 atoms. We are currently studying more complicated systems such as the CO-N2 complex embedded in such a droplet. The CO-N2  dimer remains among the most fundamental of simple van der Waals complexes and the intermolecular forces between two isoelectronic molecules: carbon monoxide (barely polar) and nitrogen (nonpolar) are of high interest from experimental and theoretical points of view. This system is of great concern in atmospheric chemistry since N2 is one of the atmosphere’s main constituents and CO is considered as an important gaseous pollutant. Precise measurements and theoretical predictions of the effects of pressure and temperature on the spectrum of CO perturbed by the dominant atmospheric species, N2 and O2, are indispensable for the interpretation of atmospheric absorption data. To that end we have developed a new, highly accurate energy surface to describe this system.

It is often useful to study simplified models in order to gain insight and clues about the behavior of the more complex system. To that end a one-dimensional model was studied in which the helium-4 atoms were confined to revolve on a ring and encircle a rotating dopant molecule. Advanced techniques of linear algebra were used to solve this problem and we observed substantial solvent decoupling – a signature of superfluidity -- for as few as 5 He-4 atoms.

The work is highly theoretical and computational and several undergraduate and graduate students have been trained in modern computational and mathematical methods in chemistry and physics. We have developed a highly parallel genetic-algorithm based quantum Monte Carlo code to study these systems. Quantum Monte Carlo methods are widely used in many fields including nuclear physics, atomic and molecular physics, materials science, and biochemistry. Finding nodal hypersurfaces is fundamental in all of these applications. Progress made towards solving the nodal problem will, we hope, have an impact in all of these areas.

Our results have been disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and talks at national and international conferences as well as in invited talks at Universities, including in Spain and Mexico. Infrastructure enhancements have included the assembly of a highly parallel, multi-core, computer cluster for use in research and teaching at Utah State University.
